text.1:
This verse explains that everything created by Allah, whether in the heavens or on earth, such as animals, plants, stones, and other things, animate or inanimate, should at all times sincerely and purely glorify Him, declare His greatness, and acknowledge that He is the Almighty. Everything submits to worship and obeys all His commands. If this is the case, then humans, as creatures endowed with reason, should sanctify Allah, carry out His commands, and avoid His prohibitions. In another verse that demonstrates the position of creation, Allah says:

"The seven heavens and the earth and whatever is in them exalt Him. And there is not a thing except that it exalts [Him] by His praise, but you do not understand their [way of] exalting. Indeed, He is ever Forbearing and Forgiving." (al-Isra'/17: 44)

He is also the All-Mighty, nothing can rival Him. He is All-Wise in creating, commanding, and regulating His creation with regulations that He has determined, in accordance with His will.
text.2: This verse explains that to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth. He is the One who has the power to do anything to His creation, to create, to give life and to cause death, to provide sustenance to whomever He wills, according to the circumstances He wills. He is the All-Powerful over all things. Whatever He wills will certainly happen, and whatever He does not will will not happen. This necessitates that humans worship Him and seek help from Him.
text.3:
In this verse, Allah states that He is the First, who existed before everything else existed, because He is the one who made them and created them. He is the Manifest (Â¨ahir), whose existence is evident due to the abundance of proofs of His existence. He is the Most High above everything; there is nothing higher than Him. He is the Hidden (Batin), whose essence cannot be described by the intellect. He knows all that is stored, that is not manifest, and all that is hidden. He is the closest to what He has created. There is nothing closer to His creation than He is; as His saying:

And We have already created man and know what his soul whispers to him, and We are closer to him than [his] jugular vein. (Qaf/50: 16)

In a hadith narrated by Ahmad and Muslim from Abu Hurairah: Fatimah came to the Prophet (saw) asking for a servant, then the Prophet told her to pray, "O Allah, Lord of everything, who revealed the Torah, the Gospel, and the Qur'an, who splits the grains. I seek refuge in You from the evil of everything. You are the one who controls it. You are the First, before whom there was nothing, You are the Last, after whom there is nothing. You are the adz-Â¨ahir, above whom there is nothing, and You are al-Bathin, below whom there is nothing. Settle our debts and fulfill our needs." (Narrated by Ahmad and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)
text.4:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah created the heavens and the earth along with everything contained within them. He is the One who governs them with a system He has determined in six periods, then He established Himself upon the 'Arsh (Throne) in a manner befitting His greatness and holiness. From there, the entire kingdom is governed with wisdom and prudence. He bestows upon some of His servants guidance that can lead them to the perfect path to serve and be grateful to Him, so that they can live happily in this world and the Hereafter. He knows all His creatures that enter into the earth; nothing escapes His knowledge. And He knows what comes out of the earth, in the form of plants, crops, and fruits, as well as substances such as gold, silver, petroleum, and so on. In another verse, Allah says:

"And with Him are the keys of the unseen; none knows them except Him. And He knows what is on the land and in the sea. Not a leaf falls but that He knows it. And no grain is there within the darknesses of the earth and no moist or dry [thing] but that it is [written] in a clear record." (al-An'am/6: 59)

Allah knows what descends from the sky, such as rain, angels, and good deeds, as Allah says in the following verse:

"Whoever desires honor [should know that] to Allah belongs all honor. To Him ascends good speech, and righteous work raises it. But those who plot evil deeds will have a severe punishment, and the plotting of those - it will perish." (Fathir/35: 10)

Allah sees all the deeds of humans wherever they are. He watches over humans, hears their words, knows what humans conceal and what moves in their hearts, as Allah says in the following verse:

"It is the same [to Him] whether any of you conceal his speech or publicizes it, and whether one is hidden by night or walks about by day." (ar-Ra'd/13: 10)
text.5:
In this verse, Allah explains that the kingdom of the heavens and the earth, along with everything within them, belongs to Him. He is the One who governs them with wise wisdom, and His decrees prevail over them according to His will and determination. To Him, all creatures and all matters will return. As He states in the following verses:

And indeed, to Us belongs the Hereafter and the first [life]. (al-Lail/92: 13)

And Allah says:

And He is Allah; there is no deity except Him. To Him is [due all] praise in the first [life] and the Hereafter. And His is the [final] decision, and to Him you will be returned. (al-Qasas/28: 70)
text.6: In this verse, Allah explains that He is the One who causes the night to enter into the day and causes the day to enter into the night according to His wisdom and the provisions He wills. Sometimes the day is longer than the night, sometimes the night is longer than the day, and sometimes they are of equal length. He created summer, winter, spring, and autumn, which are beneficial to His servants and in accordance with His plan. He is the One who knows all that is hidden, down to the smallest object, and He also knows what moves in the hearts and desires of His servants, just as He knows their good and bad deeds. With this, Allah encourages us to think deeply and carefully about all that is truly beneficial, and then to be grateful for the gifts and blessings He has bestowed, which bring us good fortune in this world and the hereafter.
text.7:
In this verse, Allah SWT commands us to believe in Him and His Messenger, and to spend from the wealth that we possess, because wealth and children are a trust from Allah to a person, and of course, one day that trust will be taken back. Syu'bah said, "I heard Qatadah narrating about Muththarif who met the Prophet SAW, he recited Surah at-Takathur, then said: Man says, "My wealth, my wealth." Your wealth is only what you have eaten and consumed, or clothing that you have worn and become worn out, or something that you have given in charity and becomes everlasting (remains). So other than that will vanish and be for others. (Narrated by Muslim)

Then Allah explains that those who believe in Allah, affirm His Messenger, and spend from the wealth that has fallen into their possession from the inheritance of those who came before, these people will receive a great reward that has never been seen nor crossed the heart.
text.8:
In this verse, Allah reproaches those who do not believe by stating, what is the reason for not believing in Allah, while His Messenger is among you, inviting you to believe and to profess His Oneness by presenting clear proofs. Regarding the faith of mankind, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) once said: "According to you, who is the most amazing in faith?" They (the Companions) replied, "The angels." The Prophet said, "How could they not believe when they are in the presence of their Lord?" Then they replied, "The Prophets." The Prophet replied, "How could they not believe when they receive revelation?" Then they said, "Then it is us." The Prophet replied, "How could you not believe when I am among you. The most amazing faith of a person is those who come after you, read the Qur'an and believe in it." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

Furthermore, Allah reproaches the disbelievers, why do you not believe, even though Allah has shown proof of His Oneness in the universe, both rationally and logically. The earth, the sky, the sea, the land, and all of Allah's creations that you witness, both in yourselves and in all of His creations, are clear evidence if you truly hold fast to Him. The meaning is that proof of the obligation to believe in Allah and His Messenger is found in all of His creations, and the Messengers have proven the truth of their da'wah and their miracles, but what is the reason you still do not want to believe?
text.9: This verse explains why disbelievers do not believe even though Allah has sent His messengers with clear proofs in order to bring them out of darkness, disbelief, into the light of faith, and from the realm of misguidance to guidance. Through His mercy, mankind is also invited to contemplate the wonders of His creation so that faith becomes more perfect.
text.10: After Allah reproached them for not wanting to believe, in this verse Allah reproaches them for not wanting to spend in His way. Why do people not want to spend the wealth that Allah has bestowed upon them in His way, when their wealth will return to Allah? If they do not spend in His way, it means they do not believe that all that wealth in reality belongs to Allah, because the heavens and the earth and all that is in them will return to Him.
text.11:
After Allah criticized them for refusing to believe, in this verse, Allah criticizes them for refusing to spend in His cause. Why are people unwilling to spend the wealth that Allah has bestowed upon them in His way, when their wealth will return to Allah? If they do not spend in His cause, it means they do not believe that all wealth, in essence, belongs to Allah, because the heavens and the earth and all that is in them will return to Him. Allah commands people to spend their wealth in the way of Allah before death, so that it becomes a treasure with Allah. This cannot be done after death because all wealth will return to Allah, the Owner of all the worlds. Furthermore, Allah SWT states the difference in degrees obtained by those who spend, due to the differences in their conditions and situations in doing so. That the degree of those who spend and emigrate before the conquest of Mecca is higher than the degree of those who spend and emigrate after it, because in the period before the conquest of Mecca, people were in a difficult situation and always threatened. No one would believe and spend except those who were truly aware, but after the conquest of Mecca, Islam had developed and people flocked to follow it. The degree of those who strive and spend before the conquest of Mecca is greater than the reward obtained by those who strive and spend after it. Qatadah said, "There are two jihads, one of which is higher in value than the other, and there are two kinds of spending, one of which is more excellent than the other; jihad and spending before the conquest of Mecca are more excellent than jihad and spending after it." But nevertheless, for each who strives and spends before or after the conquest of Mecca, there is a reward, even though there is a difference between the size of the reward. In another verse with almost the same meaning, Allah says:

Not equal are those believers who sit (at home), except those who are disabled (by injury or are blind or lame), with those who strive hard and fight in the Cause of Allah with their wealth and their lives. Allah has granted a grade higher to those who strive hard and fight with their wealth and lives than to those who sit (at home). Unto each, Allah has promised good (Paradise), but Allah has preferred those who strive hard and fight, above those who sit (at home) by a huge reward. (an-Nisa'/4: 95)

It has been narrated that there was a verbal dispute between Khalid bin al-Walid and 'Abdurrahman bin 'Auf, then Khalid said to Abdurrahman, "You consider yourself more noble than us, because you became a follower of the Prophet Muhammad SAW before us." Then the Prophet knew about Khalid's words, then he said, "Leave me to judge my companions. By Allah, in Whose hand is my soul, if you spend gold the size of Mount Uhud or the size of a mountain, you will not achieve the reward of their deeds." (Narrated by Ahmad from Anas)

"Do not revile my companions, for by Allah in Whose hand is the soul of Muhammad, if one of you were to spend gold equivalent to Mount Uhud, he would not reach one *mudd* that they gave in charity, nor even half of it." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri)

Allah says: And the first to embrace Islam of the Muhajirun and the Ansar and also those who followed them exactly (in Faith). Allah is well-pleased with them as they are well-pleased with Him. He has prepared for them Gardens under which rivers flow, to dwell therein forever. That is the supreme success. (at-Taubah/9: 100)

As a closing to this verse, Allah warns that He knows all the conditions of humans, outwardly and inwardly, therefore He will give a fitting reward. Because of His knowledge, Allah prefers the reward of spending and also jihad before the conquest of Mecca over the reward of spending and striving after it, the sincerity of spending and striving is more difficult in difficult and hard circumstances. In this case, Abu Bakr is the happiest because he has spent all his wealth in order to seek the pleasure of Allah alone.

(11) Allah invites to spend in His cause and promises those who are willing to do so. Whoever spends in the way of his Lord with the hope of getting a reward, then his Lord will multiply the reward of his spending by giving one good deed to seven hundred times and will get an unlimited reward in heaven. Ibn Mas'ud said, "Before this verse was revealed, Abu Dahdah al-Ansari asked the Prophet SAW. "O Messenger of Allah, according to my understanding, Allah actually wants a loan." "Yes, that's right, O Abu Dahdah," replied the Prophet Muhammad SAW. "O Messenger of Allah, extend your hand," then he held his hand while saying, "O Messenger of Allah, I lend my date palm garden to Allah. In it there are seven hundred date palm trees and Abu Dahdah's wife and children live there, then he said to his wife. "Get out of this garden, O my wife, with your children, because I have lent our garden to Allah," his wife replied, "Your news is true, O Abu Dahdah." Then his wife and children left the garden. Then the Prophet Muhammad SAW said, "How many springs are there in the garden belonging to Abu Dahdah."
text.12:
In this verse, it is explained that the believers will obtain a great reward in the afterlife, namely, they will be given light before them and on their right according to the amount of good deeds they performed, which leads them to Paradise. In a hadith it is mentioned: "They receive their light according to the measure of their deeds. They pass over as-sirath. Among them are those whose light is as big as a mountain, and some as big as a date palm tree, while the smallest light is as big as a thumb, sometimes it shines and sometimes it goes out." (Narrated by Ibn Jarir, Ibn Mardawaih, and al-Baihaqi)

They purify their souls with tawhid and perform righteous deeds, not associating partners with Him, so they return to Him with sincere souls and receive the record of their deeds with their right hands, as Allah states in His word:

"Then as for him who is given his record in his right hand, he will be judged with an easy account and will return to his family in joy." (al-Insyiqaq/84: 7-9) At that time, the angels say to the believer, "Rejoice in entering Paradise beneath which rivers flow as a reward commensurate with your deeds and your efforts to distance yourselves from shirk and sin, because of your constant remembrance, so be happy in your deeds." In another verse, Allah states:

"(Gardens of) 'Adn (Paradise), which they will enter, along with those who were righteous among their fathers, their spouses, and their descendants. And the angels will enter upon them from every gate, (saying), "Peace be upon you for what you patiently endured." And excellent is the final home." (ar-Ra'd/13: 23-24) As a conclusion to this verse, Allah states that the greatness of life in Paradise, the state of which is known to the believers, is a great victory that is longed for, after they are freed from Allah's punishment.
text.13: After Allah stated the condition of the believers on the Day of Judgment, in this verse, Allah reveals that the hypocrites on the Day of Judgment will call out to the believers who have attained His pleasure and become inhabitants of Paradise. "Wait for us so that we can be with you in meeting Allah, and let us take a little of your light so that we can escape through your light from the painful torment." Then this request is answered with a response that cuts off their hope and causes sadness and regret, which is, "Stay where you are, seek light there, and do not expect from us what we have done for ourselves in terms of righteous deeds, because nothing will benefit a person except their own righteous deeds." This is a mockery of them, just as they mocked the believers during their time in the world when they said: "We believe," when in fact they did not believe. This is what is intended by His saying; "Allah will mock them and leave them wandering in their transgression." (al-Baqarah/2: 15) So, to repay all their deeds, a partition is established that separates the place of the believers and the place of the hypocrites. The part occupied by the believers is Paradise, full of bliss, while the part occupied by the hypocrites is Hell, filled with torment.
text.14: Then in this verse, Allah states the events experienced by the hypocrites in the afterlife, which is that they will call out to the believers and say, "Were we not with you during our life in the world?" Then the believers will answer, "Yes, it is true, we prayed together, stood at Arafah together, fought together, and performed other religious obligations, but you indulged in pleasures and transgressions, doubted the Day of Resurrection, were deceived by wishful thinking until you said that your sins would be forgiven by Allah, because of the whispers of Satan who told you that Allah is Most Forgiving, and He will forgive your sins." The meaning is, in reality, O hypocrites, only your physical bodies were with us in the world, while your souls were not with us, you had no firmness in your stance, so you rarely remembered Allah."
text.15: In this verse, Allah explains the consequences of the actions of the hypocrites. They will continue to perish and there will be no way to escape from hell. Even if one of them wanted to redeem himself from the torment with a ransom of gold filling the entire earth, it would not be accepted. They will still be thrown into hell because there is no place more fitting for them than that. And that is the worst place.
text.16:
In this verse, Allah rebukes and warns the believers about their state of negligence. Has the time not yet come for the believers to have hearts that are soft, constantly remembering Allah, eager to listen to and understand the teachings of their religion, obedient and compliant in following the guidance of truth that has been revealed, which is laid out in the Qur'an? Furthermore, the believers are warned never to imitate the Jews and Christians who were given the Torah and the Gospel. Even though it has been a long time, they still have not followed and understood their teachings and their prophets, so that their hearts have become hardened and difficult to help, no longer able to receive advice, and the threats directed at them leave no impression on them. They change the Book in their hands and throw the teachings of their Book far away. They make their priests and pastors lords besides Allah, creating religion without reason. Most of them become *fasiq* (transgressors), abandoning their original teachings. In line with this verse is the word of Allah:

"But for their breaking of the covenant, We cursed them and made their hearts hard. They distort words from their [proper] usages and have forgotten a good portion of that which they were reminded. And you will still observe deceit among them, except a few of them. But pardon them and overlook [their misdeeds]. Indeed, Allah loves the doers of good." (al-Ma'idah/5: 13)
text.17: In this verse, Allah explains that He is the One who gives life to the earth after its death. Allah softens hardened hearts, guides astray people, removes difficulties that befall them with the explanations and guidance of the Qur'an, with advice and teachings that can soften hard stones, namely rough hearts, just as He revives and fertilizes barren, stony land with heavy rain. Thus, Allah has explained so that people can think and use their minds in the best possible way.
text.18: In this verse, Allah explains that those who affirm and believe in Allah and His Messenger, both men and women, and lend to Allah a good loan by way of giving charity and donating their wealth in the path of Allah sincerely, hoping solely for His pleasure, not desiring reward or thanks, will have their recompense multiplied by Allah SWT. One good deed performed is rewarded with ten good deeds and multiplied up to seven hundred times, and for them is a great reward and a good dwelling place, which is Jannatun na'im in the Hereafter.
text.19:
Allah SWT explains that those who believe and acknowledge the oneness of Allah SWT, affirm His messengers, and believe in what they brought from their Lord, according to Allah SWT's assessment, are on par with the *shiddiqin*, those who are extremely steadfast in their belief in the truth of the Messenger, and those who die as martyrs in the path of Allah. For them is a great reward and a brilliant light illuminating them. In line with this is Allah's statement:

"And whoever obeys Allah and the Messenger (Muhammad) - those will be with the ones upon whom Allah has bestowed favor - of the prophets, the *shiddiqin*, the martyrs and the righteous. And excellent are those as companions." (an-Nisa'/4: 69)

As for the disbelievers who deny the reasons and signs that indicate the oneness of Allah SWT and the greatness of His Messenger, they are the inhabitants of Hellfire, abiding therein forever. In line with this is Allah's statement:

"And those who disbelieve and deny Our signs - those will be companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally." (al-Baqarah/2: 39)
text.20: In this verse, Allah SWT explains to mankind that the life and pleasures of this world are merely like playthings and something amusing, becoming a source of jokes among them, as well as ornaments to complete their adornment. They boast about the wealth and offspring bestowed upon them. The world, which is temporary in nature, only lasts for a short time before disappearing and ceasing to exist. This state is no different from the earth that is hit by heavy rain, causing plants to grow that amaze the farmers, making them cheerful and happy. Then it turns dry and withered, crumbling and scattered by the wind. Furthermore, Allah SWT explains that in the Hereafter there is a severe punishment that is continuously prepared for those who love the world excessively, abandon righteous deeds, and involve themselves in polytheism and idol worship. In addition to that, there is forgiveness from Allah and His pleasure bestowed upon those who purify themselves from sin and disobedience, humble themselves to Allah and return to Him, obedient and compliant to all His commands and prohibitions. This verse 20 is concluded with a firm statement that the life of this world is only a fleeting, vanishing, and deceptive pleasure. Those who are inclined to the world will be deceived and deluded. They think that life is only in this world, and there is no life after it.
text.21:
In this verse, Allah commands mankind to hasten and compete in performing righteous deeds in order to obtain forgiveness from Allah and attain Paradise in the Hereafter, the breadth of which is as vast as the heavens and the earth, prepared for those who believe in Allah and His messengers, acknowledging the oneness of Allah and affirming His messengers. All that Allah has prepared for them is a bounty, mercy, and grace from Him. In a hadith narrated by Imam Muslim from Abu Salih from Abu Hurairah, it is explained as follows: The poor among the Muhajirin complained, "O Messenger of Allah! The rich have taken away the rewards, high ranks, and endless blessings." The Messenger of Allah asked, "What is that?" The poor Muhajirin replied, "They (the rich) pray as we pray, fast as we fast, but they give charity while we do not, they free slaves while we do not (because we are unable)." The Prophet replied, "Shall I show you an act that if you do it, you will surpass those who come after you, and no one will be more noble than you except someone who does an act like your act, namely reciting tasbih, takbir, tahmid, thirty-three times after each prayer." Abu Salih (the narrator) said, "Then the poor Muhajirin returned to the Prophet and said, 'Our rich brothers have heard of the act we are doing and they are doing what we are doing.' Then the Prophet said, 'That is the bounty of Allah which He gives to whom He wills.'" (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Salih from Abu Hurairah)

This verse concludes with the affirmation that Allah is vast in His giving and great in His bounty. He gives to whom He wills whatever He wills; He expands their sustenance in this world, bestows upon them various blessings, informs them where they should be grateful, and then rewards them in the Hereafter with a pleasing reward, which is the Paradise of Jannatun Na'im.
text.22: This verse explains that all disasters and calamities that befall the earth's surface, such as earthquakes, floods, and other natural disasters, as well as disasters that befall humans, such as accidents, illnesses, and so on, have been predetermined and written in Lauh Mahfudz, before Allah created His creation. This means that nothing happens in this universe that escapes Allah's knowledge and is not written in Lauh Mahfudz. Determining everything that will happen is very easy for Allah, because He is All-Knowing of everything, both what has already existed and what will exist in the future, both the great and the small, the visible and the invisible. This verse is a warning to some Muslims who still believe in divination, like to ask for things from graves that are considered sacred, ask about things that will happen to shamans, and so on. They should only believe in Allah alone, because He alone determines everything. Believing in the existence of supernatural powers, other than the power of Allah, is including associating Him with His creation and means not believing in the tauhid rububiyyah that exists in Allah.
text.23: In this verse, Allah SWT states that all events are decreed before they occur, so that people are patient in accepting Allah's trials. Allah's trials can sometimes be in the form of suffering and calamity, and sometimes in the form of pleasure and joy. Therefore, do not be too sad to accept the suffering and calamities that befall you, and conversely, do not be too happy and joyful to receive something that pleases you. The best attitude is to be patient in accepting disasters and calamities that befall you and to be grateful to Allah for every blessing He bestows. This verse is not to forbid Muslims from being happy and sad, but its intention is to forbid Muslims from being excessively happy and sad. 'Ikrimah said, "There is no one who is not in a state of sadness and joy, but let him make joy a sign of gratitude to Allah and sadness a sign of patience." At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that those who are too happy to receive something that pleases them and too sad to receive a disaster that befalls them are people who have signs of stinginess (tabkhil) and arrogance in themselves, as if they only think about their own interests. Allah SWT states that He does not like people who have the characteristics of stinginess and arrogance.
text.24: Those who possess arrogance and conceit are those who, when they obtain a blessing, pleasure, or wealth, believe that they acquired it solely due to their own ability and skill. They think they obtained it because of their efforts, not because of Allah's help and grace. Then Satan whispers in their ears that they are strong and capable people, not needing the help of others. Because they are confident in their own abilities, they feel they can disregard others and give to others. They believe that if they give and heed others, they will become poor. This belief is also conveyed to others, encouraging them to have the same belief, namely, to be stingy so as not to become poor. In this verse, it is emphasized that those who have such characteristics are those who turn away from Allah's commands. Allah commands people to be humble, to help one another, to assist the poor, to spend in the way of Allah, and so on, but they encourage and do the opposite. Allah states that their attitude and actions will not harm Allah in the slightest, but will harm themselves, because Allah does not need their wealth and gifts at all, but they are the ones who need it. Allah is the Most Praiseworthy because He is the One who bestows blessings upon all of His creation. Another verse with the same meaning as this verse is: "And to Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. And We have instructed those who were given the Scripture before you, and yourselves, to fear Allah. But if you disbelieve - then to Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. And ever is Allah Free of need and Praiseworthy." (an-Nisa'/4: 131)
text.25: Allah explains that He sent messengers to His people with strong evidence to prove the truth of His message. Among this evidence were the miracles given to the messengers. These miracles included not being burned by fire, as was the miracle of Prophet Ibrahim; true dreams, as was the miracle of Prophet Yusuf; the staff, as was the miracle of Prophet Musa; the Qur'an, as was the miracle of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him); and so on. Each messenger sent was tasked with conveying Allah's religion to his people. These religious teachings were sometimes written in scrolls (sahifah-sahifah) and sometimes contained in a book, such as the Torah, Zabur (Psalms), Injil (Gospel), and the Qur'an. These religious teachings serve as guidance for mankind to achieve happiness in this world and the hereafter. As a foundation for regulating and building society, every religion brought by the messengers has the principle of "justice." Justice must be upheld by the messengers and their followers in society, namely the justice of rulers towards their people, the justice of husbands as heads of households, the justice of leaders over those they lead, and so on, so that all members of society are equal in law, attitude, and treatment. In addition, Allah (SWT) bestowed upon mankind "iron," an invaluable and immeasurable blessing. With iron, various human needs can be made, from the large to the small, such as various vehicles on land, sea, and air, household necessities, and so on. With iron, humans can also build the strength of their nation and state, because iron is used to make all kinds of defense and security equipment, such as rifles, war vehicles, and so on. Of course, all of this is only permitted by Allah to be used to uphold His religion, uphold justice, and maintain the security of the country. A modern science encyclopedia describes the chemical elements on our earth as having amazing variations, some of which are difficult to find, but some are abundant. Some can be seen with the naked eye because they are in the form of liquids and solids, but some are invisible because they are in the form of gas. About 300 years ago, only 12 elements were known, including the element Ferrum (Fe), which has atomic number 26 on the Periodic Table of Elements. Fe is better known as iron. Iron is one of the easiest elements to find on Earth. It is estimated that 5% of the Earth's crust is iron. Most iron is found in the form of iron oxides, such as the minerals hematite, magnetite, and taconite. It is also strongly suspected that the Earth's surface contains many iron-nickel metal alloys. It is said that the element iron is not an original element "belonging" to the earth, but it comes from outside the earth. Experts agree that meteorites contributed to the formation of iron-nickel alloys on earth. Perhaps this is Allah's "way" of bringing the element iron to the earth's surface long before humans existed. In general, iron is a metal obtained from iron ore, and is found not in a free state but always in the form of compounds or mixtures with other elements. Therefore, to obtain the element iron, other elements must be separated, which is usually done through a chemical process. As in the steel industry, iron is widely used in the form of metal alloys. Some mixtures consist of different metals, but there are also mixtures that come from non-metals, such as carbon. All of this is done with the aim of obtaining the desired quality according to needs and with the consideration of reducing production costs. The physical properties of the element Fe, if heated continuously, will undergo a melting phase before melting. A phase where iron is in a solid state but has soft properties. Therefore, in this phase or state, iron is easily formed even with simple traditional technology such as blacksmith technology. With this simple technology, in the history of human development, the use of iron has been widely used in aspects of human daily life, including for war. Sayyid Quthub in his writing explains, "Allah sent down iron 'in which there is great strength,' that is, strength in war and peace. Then 'And so that Allah may know who helps Him and His messengers, though unseen.' This passage alludes to jihad with weapons. A presentation that is in harmony with the context of the surah which is discussing sacrifice with life and wealth." In biological knowledge, the element iron (Fe) in the form of iron is also very much needed by all organic creatures, except for a small number of bacteria. As in our bodies, iron is very necessary. In the human body, iron is mostly found in the form of stable metalloproteins, otherwise it can cause the formation of free radicals that tend to be toxic to cells. In the human body, iron is involved in the formation of red blood cells. Meanwhile, red blood cells are very important because they carry oxygen from the lungs to all the tissues in our body. Living tissue requires a supply of oxygen. The more active a tissue is, the more oxygen it needs. Iron deficiency in the blood can cause anemia, either because the number of red blood cells or because hemoglobin (a substance containing red iron that can transport oxygen) in red blood cells is reduced from normal. Allah (SWT) explains that He does this so that He may know who among His servants follows and helps the religion conveyed by the messengers He sent and who denies it. With this gift, Allah wants to test mankind and know mankind's attitude towards His blessings. People who are obedient and submissive to Allah will do all that the messengers convey, because they are sure that all their actions, attitudes, and the contents of their hearts are known to Allah, even though they do not see Allah watching over them. At the end of this verse, Allah (SWT) affirms to mankind that He is All-Powerful, nothing can defeat Him, that He is All-Mighty and no one can escape from the punishment that He has decreed.
text.26: Allah explains that He sent Noah as a messenger to his people, then He sent Abraham as a messenger to another people. It is also explained that the messengers who came later after these two messengers, all came from their descendants; there was not a single messenger sent by Allah who was not from their descendants. This can be proven true up to the last messenger, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). It is explained that not all of Noah and Abraham's descendants believed in Allah; among them were those who believed, but most of them did not believe; they were the wicked, who reduced, added to, and changed the religion brought by the messengers according to the desires of their lusts. From this verse, it is understood that a righteous servant does not necessarily mean that his child will also be a righteous servant, but it depends greatly on how a person educates and raises his child. This verse is also a stern warning from Allah to those who have believed and followed the messengers who were sent to them, but they do not follow the teachings brought by those messengers.
text.27: Thus did Allah send the messengers, followed by subsequent messengers, to convey His religion to mankind, so that mankind would have no excuse on the Day of Judgment to say why they were punished when no messenger had been sent to them. In this verse, Allah specifically mentions Jesus because many of his followers were wicked, namely altering, adding to, and subtracting from the teachings conveyed by Jesus. It is explained that Jesus is the son of Maryam, given the Gospel (Injil), containing the core teachings to be used as guidance by his people in achieving happiness in life in this world and the hereafter, and as a completion of Allah's teachings contained in the Torah that had been revealed to Prophet Musa previously. Then, the characteristics of the followers of Prophet Jesus are explained: 1. Allah SWT placed in their hearts a feeling of mutual support for one another, they strive to avoid destruction that comes to them and their brothers and sisters, and strive to repair the destruction that occurs to them. 2. Among themselves, there is a relationship of affection and a desire for goodness in themselves. Even though they possessed praiseworthy and good qualities as taught by Prophet Jesus, they committed wickedness, namely inventing *rahbaniyyah* (monasticism), by establishing the rule of prohibiting marriage for their priests, even though marriage is a *sunnah* of Allah established for His creation. They established this *rabbaniyah* with the intention of drawing closer to Allah, but Allah never established it. Therefore, they are people who like to invent something that contradicts the *sunnatullah* (Allah's way), namely not prescribing marriage for their priests, the purpose of which is to continue offspring and maintain the continuity of human life. Another wicked act they committed was that they had altered, added to, and subtracted from the religion brought by Prophet Jesus, which is contained in the Gospel, because they followed their desires. At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that He will give manifold rewards to those who believe, follow the *sharia* brought by the messengers, do not invent things that are not, and do not add to or alter His books. As for those wicked people, they will be afflicted with a very severe punishment.
text.28:
Allah swt commanded the Children of Israel who had believed in Isa bin Maryam as His messenger and envoy to believe in Muhammad saw who came after him, to follow his commands and abstain from his prohibitions contained in the Al-Qur'an and Hadith. This command essentially reinforces Allah's command contained in the Gospel (Injil) revealed to Prophet Isa. If the Children of Israel followed Allah swt's command, then Allah promised them a double reward, greater than the reward that would be received by those who only believed in Prophet Muhammad saw. In addition, He would forgive their sins, because He forgives the sins of whomever He wills. If what Allah promised to the followers of Prophet Isa and they also believed in Muhammad is: 1. They will be granted a double reward. 2. They will be illuminated with the light of guidance in facing tribulations and disasters on the Day of Judgment and in heading towards the paradise full of bliss. 3. Allah swt will forgive the sins they have committed.

In the hadith below, it is explained who will receive a double reward, namely: Narrated by ash-Sha'biy from Abu Burdah from his father Abu Musa al-Asy'ari, he said, "The Messenger of Allah saw said, 'There are three types of people who are given a double reward, namely: a person from the People of the Book who believed in his prophet and also believed in me, then for him is a double reward; and a slave who fulfills the rights of Allah and the rights of his master, then for him is a double reward; and a person who educates his female slave well, then frees her and marries her, then for him is a double reward as well.'" (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)
text.29: In this verse, Allah rejects the opinion of the Children of Israel who said that messengers and prophets were only appointed from their descendants. Allah appointed Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) not from the descendants of the Children of Israel, so that they would know that only He determines everything, and that those who will receive a double reward are only the People of the Book who believe in Muhammad (peace be upon him). If they do not believe in Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), they will not receive any reward at all. At the end of this verse, Allah explains that He has boundless bounty, which He will bestow upon whomever He wills.
